file_metadata.title: Scalable sim-to-real transfer of soft robot designs

chunks.text: The manual design of soft robots and their controllers is challenging, but automated design tools could augment or replace this process. Machine learning can automate design proposal, testing, and refinement in simulation, with promising designs then manufactured (sim2real). However, preserving simulated behavior in reality is an open question. While prior studies have explored sim2real transfer of control policies, the impact of morphology on the simulation-reality gap remains largely unexplored, partly due to a lack of tools for systematic design and rapid manufacturing. This work introduces a low-cost, open-source, modular soft robot design and construction kit to simulate, fabricate, and measure the simulation-reality gap of minimally complex soft, locomoting machines. The scalability of this approach is demonstrated by transferring a significantly larger number of robot designs from simulation to reality compared to previous methods.
chunks.chunk_summary: Automated design tools using machine learning can improve soft robot design, but the impact of morphology on sim2real transfer remains understudied, necessitating new tools for systematic design and manufacturing.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: The simulation-reality gap for rigid-bodied robots is narrowing due to improved computational models and tuning, enabling successful transfer of simulated control policies. However, the gap for soft robots remains uncharted. Soft bodies are more challenging to simulate, design, and control precisely, but their inherent compliance makes them more tolerant to inaccuracies. Quantifying which soft robot designs, policies, and behaviors can be faithfully simulated is crucial for both robotics and synthetic biology, as real-world testing is expensive, time-consuming, and potentially risky. Recent advancements in high-space, many-body, GPU-accelerated soft body simulators have made sim2real more feasible, but their transferability remains unknown due to limited application in physical system design.
chunks.chunk_summary: While the simulation-reality gap is closing for rigid robots, it remains uncharted for soft robots, which are more complex to simulate but also more tolerant to inaccuracies.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: Previous work has demonstrated sim2real transfer of soft object manipulation but not soft robot behavior. For example, a rigid robot arm was trained in simulation to fold towels and drape cloth, but the reality gap was only assessed by binary task success, and the robot's geometry was fixed. Hiller and Lipson evolved the geometry and material distribution of cantilever beams and transferred their passive dynamics. They also evolved the morphology and behavior of soft robots in simulation and physically built one design, but its transfer required a pressure and vacuum chamber. Kriegman et al. explored damage recovery in simulated soft robots and transferred recovery strategies to physical silicone "voxels," but locomotion failed due to the robot's weight, high-friction feet, and symmetrical actuation.
chunks.chunk_summary: Previous sim2real studies have focused on soft object manipulation or limited morphology transfer, highlighting the need for improved methods for transferring soft robot behavior.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: This work presents a soft robot design and construction kit based on miniaturized silicone voxel modules, simplified for improved reproducibility and arbitrary actuation for locomotion transfer. Unlike existing modular rigid-bodied robot kits, this kit is easier, faster, cheaper, and safer, using hollow silicone voxels and tubing for low-pressure actuation via a hand pump. The kit is used to measure the reality gap as a function of morphology, fabricating 108 morphologies and comparing the behavior of nine simulated designs with their silicone counterparts. The kit's affordability, safety, speed, and simplicity aim to generate more and more reproducible data on automated soft robot design.
chunks.topic: Soft Robot Design and Construction Kit
chunks.chunk_summary: A new low-cost, open-source, modular soft robot kit is introduced to facilitate sim2real transfer and measure the reality gap as a function of morphology.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: The design space consists of a 2x2x2 cartesian lattice workspace where voxels can be passive, actuated, or absent, resulting in 3⁸ = 6561 possible configurations. Each configuration was evaluated in simulation using the Voxelyze soft-body physics engine, which models distances between adjacent voxels as Euler-Bernoulli beams. A collision detection system creates temporary beams between intersecting surface voxels. Simulations used gravity (-9.81 m/s²), an infinite surface plane at z=0, Coulomb friction, and voxel properties (1 cm³ resting volume, 10⁷ Pa Young's modulus, 0.35 Poisson's ratio, 1 and 0.5 static and kinetic friction coefficients). Volumetric actuation was implemented by varying rest length between voxels, limited to +90% expansion. Active voxels expand in phase with a 4 Hz sine wave, producing quasistatic dynamics.
chunks.chunk_summary: The design space comprises 6561 voxel configurations simulated in Voxelyze with defined physical parameters and volumetric actuation.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: Each design was simulated for 4 seconds, with an initial settling period of 0.25 seconds before actuation. Fitness was defined as the net displacement of the center of mass in the x-y plane from its initial position after 15 actuation cycles (3.75 seconds). An exhaustive search of all 6561 designs took 58 CPU hours on a 16-core processor.
chunks.chunk_summary: Simulations ran for 4 seconds, with fitness measured as the net displacement of the center of mass after 15 actuation cycles.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: Physical voxels were created as pneumatically-actuated, hollow silicone structures.  Previous work had limitations due to symmetrical actuation and weight issues, resulting in only shape change transfer, not locomotion. The current kit addresses these by miniaturizing voxels, simplifying inter-voxel connections, and enabling arbitrary actuation.  This allows for asymmetrical actuation and improved weight support, facilitating locomotion.
chunks.chunk_summary: Miniaturized, pneumatically-actuated silicone voxels were fabricated, addressing previous limitations in weight and actuation to enable locomotion transfer.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: Voxels were manufactured using a rotational molding machine. An open-face mold, resembling an ice-cube tray, was fabricated from laser-cut acrylic strips. Silicone with colored pigment (pink for active, blue/yellow for passive) was poured into the mold and spread evenly. The mold was then rotated on a machine at 45° for even coating. After partial curing at room temperature, the mold was incubated at 60°C.  The process was repeated for a second layer. Bottomless voxels were removed, trimmed, and assembled into slices using Sil-Poxy. Holes were punched between active voxels for contiguous actuation. A bottom layer was created by pouring silicone between rulers on an acrylic substrate, and the voxel slice was placed on it.
chunks.chunk_summary: A detailed protocol describes the fabrication of silicone voxels using a rotational molding process, including mold preparation, silicone pouring, curing, and assembly into slices.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: After the bottom layer cured, silicone was applied to bond adjacent voxels without covering inter-voxel holes. The slice was cut, holes poked into exterior active voxels, and silicone tubing inserted and glued.  Tubes were connected to pneumatic connectors and then to larger tubing. Leaks were detected by submerging voxels in water and inflating, then repaired with Sil-Poxy. Finally, slices were stacked and bonded with silicone, and pneumatically connected.
chunks.chunk_summary: The assembly process involved bonding voxels, inserting tubing for pneumatic actuation, and addressing potential leaks to create functional robot structures.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: The 8D ternary morphology design space was visualized as a 2D heatmap by nesting dimensions, similar to Cully et al.'s visualization of control policy fitness. The center pixel represents all passive voxels (F=0), the top right corner represents all active voxels (F=0 due to symmetrical actuation), and the bottom left corner represents no voxels (F=0).  Locomotion requires a body and asymmetrical mass/actuator distribution for open-loop, in-phase actuation. Clusters and lines of similarly colored pixels indicate morphologically similar designs with similar fitness, suggesting stability under mutations or fabrication errors.
chunks.chunk_summary: The 8D design space was visualized as a 2D heatmap, revealing clusters of similar fitness and highlighting the importance of asymmetry for locomotion.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: Due to the fitness measure (displacement in any direction), rotations of a single geometry with similar fitness exist, reflected across planes of symmetry in the heatmap and observed in manufactured robots. The uniqueness of designs depends on how behavior is measured.
chunks.chunk_summary: Rotational symmetry in the design space leads to multiple configurations with similar fitness, highlighting the influence of the fitness measure on design uniqueness.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: Nine designs were tested in both simulation and reality (actuated 90 times at 6 kPa on a cornstarch-covered surface). Seven designs filled the cubic workspace, while two had a single-voxel limb attached to a 2x2 plane (one with an active limb, the other passive). These two achieved the highest fitness in both simulation and reality. While the reality gap appeared small based on net displacement, the simulated and physical robots moved differently. The simulated design with an active limb pushed off it, while the physical robot pulled itself forward with the limb. Similarly, the simulated design with a passive limb pushed off its torso, while the physical robot pulled itself forward with it.
chunks.chunk_summary: Nine designs were compared in simulation and reality, revealing differences in locomotion despite similar fitness scores, suggesting a larger reality gap than initially apparent.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: The differing locomotion directions between simulation and reality are hypothesized to be due to differences in tribological properties, as demonstrated by Majidi et al., where locomotion direction depended on surface friction. A grid search of simulation hyperparameters, including friction coefficients, even with increased surface contact resolution by simulating subvoxels, failed to match simulated and real movement directions for all designs. This suggests the Coulomb friction model may be insufficient, as it doesn't account for surface area and interfacial shear strength. Future work will explore noisy environments and imperfect actuation control, data-driven tuning of simulation parameters, and physical surfaces with varied tribological properties.
chunks.chunk_summary: Discrepancies in locomotion direction between simulation and reality are likely due to oversimplified friction models, necessitating further investigation of tribological properties and simulation parameters.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: This paper introduced a low-cost, open-source platform for designing and building soft robots, transferring 108 morphologies from simulation to reality and measuring the reality gap for nine designs. While net displacement showed a small gap, velocity revealed a wider gap due to simplified tribological contacts. The 99 unactuated transferred designs served as sketches, enabling broader design space exploration before full construction. This breadth-first approach, using sketches at different levels of realism, is crucial for complex robot design, especially for soft robots. The kit's affordability and ease of use can contribute to a growing database of soft robot designs and their transferability.
chunks.chunk_summary: The presented platform facilitated the transfer of numerous soft robot designs, highlighting the importance of a breadth-first approach using sketches and revealing the influence of tribological contacts on the reality gap.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: The typical sim2real approach of policy search with a single robot design is contrasted with the iterative, breadth-first approach of architectural design, which uses sketches at increasing levels of detail. Soft robot design, being more complex, requires even greater breadth of sketches. The data from this work contributes to prior knowledge about soft robot design transferability, and the construction kit can further expand this data by lowering the barrier to entry for non-experts.
chunks.chunk_summary: A breadth-first design approach using sketches at different levels of realism is advocated for complex soft robot design, contrasting with the typical single-design, policy-search approach.
chunks.authors: ["Sam Kriegman", "Amir Mohammadi Nasab", "Dylan Shah", "Hannah Steele", "Gabrielle Branin", "Michael Levin", "Josh Bongard", "Rebecca Kramer-Bottiglio"]

chunks.text: The generality of this data beyond robotics, particularly for developmental biology and regenerative medicine, is discussed.  Reverse-engineering bioelectric and genetic control policies through machine learning could enable controlled regeneration and reprogramming of cancerous growth.  However, this requires transferable hypotheses between simulation and reality.
chunks.chunk_summary: The findings have potential implications for biology and medicine, particularly in regenerative medicine and cancer research, by enabling the transfer of simulated hypotheses to real-world applications.
